At the age of 13, he moved to New Orleans with his mother, taking care of himself while pursuing his passion for performing. Perry's love for entertainment was ignited by the local theater scene, where he began participating in school productions and local plays.

After completing high school, Perry attended New Orleans' Dillard University but did not graduate. Instead, he pursued his acting career in Chicago, where he began developing his trademark storytelling style. Perry created his famous stage characters and theatrical productions, which soon garnered attention and admiration from theatergoers.

In 1996, Perry moved to Atlanta, Georgia, where he continued to hone his acting and writing skills. His success on stage led to opportunities in film and television. Perry's first foray into filmmaking came in 2005 with the release of "Diary of a Mad Black Woman," based on his popular stage plays. The film went on to earn him a Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy, and it marked the beginning of a string of successful films, including "Madea's Family Reunion" and the critically acclaimed "A Madea Christmas."

Perry's TV series, "Meet the Browns" (2009) and "House of Payne" (2006-2012), further solidified his position as a prominent figure in the entertainment industry. Perry's work has earned him numerous accolades, including multiple Golden Globes, Emmys, and NAACP Image Awards.
